items.title: TiVo confirms that it exited the hardware business on October 1 when it stopped selling DVRs, but says it will continue to offer support for the products (Michael Schneider/Variety)
bullets: TiVo stopped selling DVRs on Oct 1, exiting its hardware business.
The company confirmed it will continue to offer support for existing products.
Marks the end of an era for a pioneering time-shifting TV device.
items.why_it_matters: This move signals the end of a once-innovative home entertainment device, reflecting the shift in media consumption towards streaming and digital services.

items.title: A new study of 6,554 children aged 9 to 10 found that social media users scored lower on reading, vocabulary, and memory tests two years later than non-users (Rhitu Chatterjee/NPR)
bullets: Study of 6,554 children (9-10) linked social media use to lower test scores.
Users performed poorer in reading, vocabulary, and memory two years later.
Findings suggest potential negative cognitive impact on pre-teens.
items.why_it_matters: This research highlights potential long-term cognitive risks for young social media users, urging caution and further study into the effects of screen time on child development.

items.title: A look at quick commerce in India and China: India's ecosystem is evolving into a retail-media play, while China's is being used as a weapon in platform wars (Manish Singh/India Dispatch)
bullets: Quick commerce in India is evolving into a retail-media platform.
In China, quick commerce is being utilized as a weapon in platform wars.
Globally, quick commerce has struggled or stalled in many markets.
items.why_it_matters: This analysis shows diverse strategies and challenges for quick commerce, indicating varying market maturity and competitive landscapes across different regions.

items.title: Dealroom: 230+ European defense tech startups have launched since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, driven by interest in drones, as investors foresee a shake-out (Sylvia Pfeifer/Financial Times)
bullets: Over 230 European defense tech startups launched since Ukraine invasion.
Growth is largely driven by increased interest in drone technology.
Investors anticipate a consolidation or 'shake-out' in the sector.
items.why_it_matters: This reflects a surge in defense innovation fueled by geopolitical events, but also points to potential market saturation and intense competition among new ventures.

items.title: Nvidia says it is donating the Vera Rubin NVL144 server rack architecture to the Open Compute Project and outlines its vision for "gigawatt AI factories" (Mike Wheatley/SiliconANGLE)
bullets: Nvidia donated Vera Rubin NVL144 server architecture to Open Compute Project.
Outlined its vision for "gigawatt AI factories" at the OCP Global Summit.
Aims to enable massive-scale, energy-intensive AI infrastructure.
items.why_it_matters: Signifies Nvidia's commitment to open standards and its ambitious plans for future AI data centers, which will shape the development of large-scale AI infrastructure.

items.title: Researchers used an off-the-shelf system to compile a vast collection of private data, including T-Mobile users' calls and texts, sent by satellites unencrypted (Wired)
bullets: Researchers found private data leaked via unencrypted satellite transmissions.
Used basic, off-the-shelf equipment (costing ~$800) for collection.
Data included T-Mobile user calls/texts, military, and corporate info.
items.why_it_matters: This exposes a critical vulnerability in satellite communications, highlighting an urgent need for stronger encryption to protect private and sensitive information.

items.title: Sources: Tata Electronics bought the Indian unit of Justech Precision, a China-based Apple supplier that provides CNC machines to Foxconn, for ~$100M in August (Anniek Bao/CNBC)
bullets: Tata Electronics acquired Justech Precision's Indian unit for ~$100M.
Justech is a China-based Apple supplier for CNC machines to Foxconn.
The deal happened in August, as per sources.
items.why_it_matters: This acquisition strengthens India's role in Apple's supply chain and boosts local electronics manufacturing capabilities.

items.title: Bhutan announces that it is migrating its national ID system for roughly 800,000 residents from Polygon to Ethereum, with completion expected by Q1 2026 (Brayden Lindrea/Cointelegraph)
bullets: Bhutan is moving its national ID system for 800,000 residents.
The migration is from Polygon to the Ethereum blockchain.
Expected completion is by Q1 2026.
items.why_it_matters: This showcases growing government adoption of blockchain technology for crucial national services like identity management.

items.title: Indian officials say that over the past year, all 1.2M email addresses of Central Government employees migrated to a platform developed by Chennai-based Zoho (The Hindu)
bullets: 1.2 million Indian Central Government emails migrated to Zoho's platform.
The migration was completed over the last year.
Zoho is a Chennai-based company.
items.why_it_matters: This is a significant adoption of a domestic tech solution by the Indian government, supporting local businesses.

items.title: Mumbai-based wealth management startup Dezerv raised a ~$40M Series C co-led by Premji Invest and Accel's Global Growth Fund, taking its total funding to ~$100M (Shashank Pathak/Entrackr)
bullets: Dezerv, a Mumbai wealth management startup, secured ~$40M Series C.
Funding round co-led by Premji Invest and Accel's Global Growth Fund.
Total funding for Dezerv now reaches approximately ~$100M.
items.why_it_matters: Highlights strong investor confidence in India's wealth management tech sector and the country's startup ecosystem.

items.title: Researchers detail "Pixnapping", a new covert attack to steal 2FA codes and other private data on Android; Google's September patch only partially mitigates it (Dan Goodin/Ars Technica)
bullets: New Android attack, "Pixnapping," steals 2FA codes and private data.
Attack is covert and can steal data in under 30 seconds.
Google's September patch provides only partial mitigation.
items.why_it_matters: Android users remain vulnerable to critical data theft, requiring continued vigilance against new and evolving security threats.
key_commands: Check for OS updates frequently and install them.
Be cautious with app permissions, especially screen recording/accessibility.
Use hardware 2FA keys if available for enhanced security.
caveats: The September patch does not fully fix this vulnerability.
Users should be extra vigilant about suspicious app behavior.
This exploit targets sensitive on-screen information.

items.title: The UK's NCSC dealt with a record 204 "nationally significant" cyberattacks in the year to August, up 89% YoY, and "highly significant" cyberattacks rose by 50% (Joe Tidy/BBC)
bullets: UK's NCSC handled a record 204 major cyberattacks to August.
This marks an 89% increase in a year for nationally significant attacks.
"Highly significant" cyberattacks also rose by 50%.
items.why_it_matters: Indicates a sharp increase in cyber threats, emphasizing the urgent need for enhanced digital security measures across the UK.

items.title: California Gov. Gavin Newsom vetoes SB 771, which would've fined social media companies if their algorithms intentionally promoted violent or extremist content (Tyler Katzenberger/Politico)
bullets: CA Gov. Newsom vetoed SB 771.
The bill aimed to fine social media firms for promoting violent content via algorithms.
Newsom stated concerns but called the bill 'premature'.
items.why_it_matters: This veto protects tech companies from potential penalties related to their content algorithms, influencing future efforts to regulate online hate speech.

items.title: Nvidia says it will begin selling the DGX Spark mini PC for AI developers on October 15 on Nvidia.com and select third-party retailers for $3,999 (Michael Kan/PCMag)
bullets: Nvidia to launch DGX Spark mini PC for AI developers.
Available Oct 15 for $3,999 on Nvidia.com & select retailers.
This is a specialized mini-PC, not intended for general consumers.
items.why_it_matters: This provides a compact, powerful tool for AI developers, potentially accelerating AI research and innovation by making specialized hardware more accessible.

items.title: Samsung projects Q3 operating profit up 32% YoY to ~$8.47B, vs. ~$6.8B est., its biggest quarterly profit in over three years, as AI development accelerates (Yoolim Lee/Bloomberg)
bullets: Samsung forecasts Q3 operating profit to rise 32% YoY to ~$8.47B.
This exceeds estimates of ~$6.8B, marking its highest in 3+ years.
The strong profit is attributed to accelerating AI development and demand.
items.why_it_matters: Samsung's robust financial performance underscores the significant positive impact of the global AI boom on major tech companies, especially in the chip sector.
